text: Man alive, Jarrett and Valenting punk'd a couple of beginners with compiler spells.

text: Lol, yep. It’s hard to take the compiler nerd/enthusiast out of a person to answer questions very generally

text: Is TTFP a real problem? Well no, except when TTFP means 10minute startup of your climate model

elements.text: Is TTFP a real problem? Well no, except when TTFP means 10minute startup of your climate model

text: All good though - lots of people were asking about Tensorflow stuff and its good that people with compiler knowledge could answer.

elements.text: All good though - lots of people were asking about Tensorflow stuff and its good that people with compiler knowledge could answer.

text:
> No no, please, let's talk about docker + kubernetes compilation pipelines beginners love the cloud
Ha, I guess one interesting thing here is that "beginner" can mean different things :grin:

Since starting Beacon and doing 100+ interviews with devs, I've come to realize that there's a pretty large audience of potential industry users that are very interested in Julia from a data engineering perspective but can be culturally thrown off by the vast majority of intro material that's more focused on the MATLAB-user-who-wants-to-escape-MATLAB audience.

Whereas a beginner scientific user might think "But how do I do basic interactive plots? How do I run this on the GPU? How do I get access to XYZ linalg kernel?",  these beginner eng-focused users are thinking "where's the basic simple spin-up-a-container-in-my-AWS-account hello-world example? Can I just run Julia alongside/within all my other tools?"  For these people, having to install/run things OUTSIDE of Docker just to get started can actually seem like a big burden (which is unsurprising if they're used to the nightmarish packaging situations of certain other languages lol).

So one reason I've started really highlighting the Docker + K8s + Julia combo more when I speak to a general beginner audience is to reach THOSE folks. Because I want to hire them :smiling_imp: and also because I think adoption in that space is actually pretty feasible + important for the growth of the ecosystem at large

text: All for it. Diversity is good!

elements.text: All for it. Diversity is good!
